1.sofaString: THE ANTI-CHRISTIAN MOVEMENT                 May 20.                 FEW realize with any adequate appreciation the significant service being rendered by the National Christian Council of China both through its membership scattered throughout the land and through its effective central office force and working                 committees Meeting quietly in the hall of Union Church with out the slightest public demon stration without the externals of entertainment in the form of banquets and receptions such as are frequently tendered to visiting delegations this group of nearly hundred persons represents one of the most truly constructive forces in China The very bringing together of information would be valuable if that were all The Anti- Narcotic Committee of the Council is striking illustration Through its activity the Nation al Anti-Opium Association was brought into being in the autumn of 1924, and has been able within few months to launch inquiries and collate in formation regarding the nation al situation No other source is so well-informed as the mis Scattered as they' are oven in remote places in distant provinces they see they record accurately and they report fully Only by continuing to shed light on the oppression of militarists that leads to the planting of opium and to increasing its use can the evil be eventually eliminated Or consider the report of the Industrial Committee of the Council Reginning with con siderable piece of research in regard to the use of phosphorus conducted during the year by Dr Maitland other investigations are reported such as the Apprenticeship System in Ningpo Child Labour in Canton Child Labour in Shang hai by the Municipal Council the Silk Industry in Kuangtung Province and other inquiries So too in the realm of educa tion significant information has been brought together by the Council or its associated bodies Work for the blind has been studied delegates have been set                 to investigate rural pro- and the country church md in many other fields scarce- thought of by the average facts have been gleaned But the National Christian Council is far more than of inquiry Created by he Christian Conference that net in Shanghai in May 1922, is body representing the Christian movement throughout Dhina and as such endeavours serve churches and missions Uike but without dealing with of faith and order Vlany major topics have received during the sessions of he third annual meeting which lave continued for week past md terminate this evening We io well to note some of them Every thoughtful observer has conscious during the past rear the increasing l orce and extent of the Anti-Christian movement Differing from the Boxer movement of 1900 largely in this that it is impelled by an intelligent and greatly awakened national consciousness the Anti- Christian movement has shown its force of late chiefly by its attacks on Christian schools and colleges throughout the land Appeals are being issued for reclaiming of educational control which many allege has been lost to foreigners All forms of religious education must be eliminated even from private schools foreign influence must not continue and many other virulent prohibitions have been uttered in the name of education al patriotism The National Christian Coun cil has been exceedingly wise in its approach to this difficult problem Instead of planning debates or encouraging argu mentation in the press it has set itself to plan true forward movement by the Church throughout China This will include study of the questions that cause resentment such as foreign relations the use of foreign flags etc It will in clude plan for constructive religious teaching in schools so that the essence of Christianity may come to be understood and every encouragement to adapting its forms to the Chin ese environment It will plan to promote leadership in church and school work by trained Chinese leaders It will en to encourage Christian schools everywhere to pay in creasing attention to teaching national spoken language and to Chinese literature and learning and will urge all missionaries to understand the background of Chinese civilisation by more attention to study of the language and to cultivating friendships But above all it will seek to show in the lives of individuals who bear the Christian name as well as in the corporate activities of Christian bodies the essential spiritual message of Christianity For in the long run the Christian religion must be seen to be what it really is religion of love not de pendent for its power 011 Gov ernmental relationships but fallowing of the person and the spirit of its great founder
